citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The licensee changed his Attending Veterinarian 4-6 months ago. His current Attending Veterinarian has not filled out a
new program of veterinary care. Not having the new Attending Veterinarian fill out a program of veterinary care doesn't
ensure the dogs in the kennel are receiving adequate veterinary care. The licensee must have the new Attending
Veterinarian fill out a new program of veterinary care for dogs. Correct by 1/2/24.

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
During examination, a brown and white adult female Shih Tzu (ID #071) was found to have matted fur containing fecal
material around the anus. The fur is being twisted due to the matting so that the skin is slightly pulled. The licensee had
not observed this prior to inspection. Matted fur can cause irritation, trauma, and infection to the skin. Not doing thorough
observations on a daily basis can cause the licensee to miss medical and grooming issues such as what was noted
above. Correct by trimming of matted fur and provide daily observation of all animals to ensure the health and well-being
of the dogs. Correct by 12/19/2023.

The licensee has 57 adult dogs in the kennel. APHIS Form 7005 only shows that there is 44 adult dogs and is missing 13
of the adult dogs. Not having APHIS Form 7005 updated with all the current dogs in the kennel doesn't allow APHIS
officials to be able to properly track all of the licensee's dogs. The licensee must update his APHIS Form 7005 to include
all regulated dogs in the kennel. Correct by 12/26/23.

There is no documentation showing that the contingency plan has been reviewed by the licensee in the past year. Not
reviewing the contingency plan on an annual basis doesn't ensure the contingency plan adequately addresses the needs
of the kennel in case of an emergency. The contingency plan must be reviewed on an annual basis. This review must be
documented and the documentation must be made available for inspection. Correct by 12/26/23.

The licensee changed his Attending Veterinarian 4-6 months ago. The new Attending Veterinarian hasn't filled out a new
exercise plan. Not having an exercise plan filled out by the Attending Veterinarian doesn't ensure the dogs are receiving
daily exercise. The licensee must have the Attending Veterinarian fill out a new exercise plan. Correct by 1/2/24.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
None of the dog plastic J-type food receptacles are on a sanitation schedule. The cage surfaces and cracks surrounding
the food receptacles contains buildup of food waste and dog fur debris. Cleanliness of food receptacles is important for
ensuring the health of the dogs and prevention of disease. Correct by ensuring food and water receptacles are sanitized
and are on a schedule for future sanitation at least once every two weeks or more often if necessary to prevent
accumulation of dirt, debris, food waste, excreta, and other disease hazards. Correct by 12/26/23.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
End of report.
Additional Inspectors:
Kem Singletary, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.40(a)(1) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
The licensee changed his Attending Veterinarian 4-6 months ago. His current Attending Veterinarian has not filled out a 
new program of veterinary care. Not having the new Attending Veterinarian fill out a program of veterinary care doesn't 
ensure the dogs in the kennel are receiving adequate veterinary care. The licensee must have the new Attending 
Veterinarian fill out a new program of veterinary care for dogs. Correct by 1/2/24. 
2.40(b)(3) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
During examination, a brown and white adult female Shih Tzu (ID #071) was found to have matted fur containing fecal 
material around the anus. The fur is being twisted due to the matting so that the skin is slightly pulled. The licensee had 
not observed this prior to inspection. Matted fur can cause irritation, trauma, and infection to the skin. Not doing thorough 
observations on a daily basis can cause the licensee to miss medical and grooming issues such as what was noted 
above. Correct by trimming of matted fur and provide daily observation of all animals to ensure the health and well-being 
of the dogs. Correct by 12/19/2023. 
2.75(a)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
The licensee has 57 adult dogs in the kennel. APHIS Form 7005 only shows that there is 44 adult dogs and is missing 13 
of the adult dogs. Not having APHIS Form 7005 updated with all the current dogs in the kennel doesn't allow APHIS 
officials to be able to properly track all of the licensee's dogs. The licensee must update his APHIS Form 7005 to include 
all regulated dogs in the kennel. Correct by 12/26/23. 
2.134(b) 
   
Contingency planning. 
There is no documentation showing that the contingency plan has been reviewed by the licensee in the past year. Not 
reviewing the contingency plan on an annual basis doesn't ensure the contingency plan adequately addresses the needs 
of the kennel in case of an emergency. The contingency plan must be reviewed on an annual basis. This review must be 
documented and the documentation must be made available for inspection. Correct by 12/26/23.

3.8 
   
Exercise for dogs. 
The licensee changed his Attending Veterinarian 4-6 months ago. The new Attending Veterinarian hasn't filled out a new 
exercise plan. Not having an exercise plan filled out by the Attending Veterinarian doesn't ensure the dogs are receiving 
daily exercise. The licensee must have the Attending Veterinarian fill out a new exercise plan. Correct by 1/2/24. 
3.11(b)(2) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
None of the dog plastic J-type food receptacles are on a sanitation schedule. The cage surfaces and cracks surrounding 
the food receptacles contains buildup of food waste and dog fur debris. Cleanliness of food receptacles is important for 
ensuring the health of the dogs and prevention of disease. Correct by ensuring food and water receptacles are sanitized 
and are on a schedule for future sanitation at least once every two weeks or more often if necessary to prevent 
accumulation of dirt, debris, food waste, excreta, and other disease hazards. Correct by 12/26/23. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee. 
 
End of report. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Kem Singletary, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
